newsitem.title: UK: Hickson Intl sells unit, takes charge.
newsitem.headline: Hickson Intl sells unit, takes charge.

text.p: Specialty chemicals group Hickson International Plc said on Monday it had agreed to sell its Hickson Manro unit to a management buyout team for 26.5 million stg.
The company said the sale resulted in an exceptional loss, net of expenses, of about 16 million stg, after charging 18 million stg of goodwill previously written-off to reserves.
Hickson said it had sold the surfactants unit, which has plants in Stalybridge, England, and Renory, Belgium, to Broomco Ltd.
The buyers intended to operate the business under the Manro name, Hickson said in a statement.
The company said it would use proceeds from the sale to reduce its debt, which was about 70 million stg at June 30 on a pro forma basis, taking into account the disposal.
"Overall, the group's trading performance remains in line with the board's expectations," the company said.
The sale is the latest in a series of disposals aimed at turning round Yorkshire-based Hickson.
The company crashed to a pretax loss of 45 million pounds in 1995 after a pretax profit of 19.2 million stg a year earlier.
It was hit by poor trading conditions and the cancellation of a key detergent supply contract late in 1994.
